<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Jakarta skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Jakarta</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_dmy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use dmy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use dmy dates</a>
</p><p>{{#invoke:Infobox|infobox}}
</p><p><b>Jakarta</b> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[note 1]</a></sup> officially known as the <b>Special Capital Region of Jakarta</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-id&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-id (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-id</a>), is the capital and largest city of <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>.
</p><p>Located on the northwest coast of <a href="/wiki/Java" title="Java">Java</a>, Jakarta is the country's economic, cultural and political centre, and with a population of 10,187,595 as of November 2011,<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[1]</a></sup> it is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_urban_areas_by_population&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of urban areas by population (page does not exist)">most populous city</a> in Indonesia and in Southeast Asia, and is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_proper_by_population" title="List of cities proper by population">thirteenth most populated city</a> in the world. The official metropolitan area, known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greater_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greater Jakarta (page does not exist)">Jabodetabek</a> (a name formed by combining the initial syllables of Jakarta, <a href="/wiki/Bogor" title="Bogor">Bogor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Depok" title="Depok">Depok</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tangerang" title="Tangerang">Tangerang</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bekasi" title="Bekasi">Bekasi</a>), is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_urban_areas_by_population&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of urban areas by population (page does not exist)">second largest</a> in the world, yet the metropolis's suburbs still continue beyond it.  Jakarta is listed as a <a href="/wiki/Global_city" title="Global city">global city</a> in the 2008 Globalization and World Cities Study Group and Network (GaWC) research.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[2]</a></sup> and has an area of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.  This area has a population of well over 28 million,<sup id="cite_ref-bps_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bps-4">[3]</a></sup> making it one of the world's largest conurbations in terms of number of inhabitants.
</p><p>In 2011, Jakarta ranked 17th among the world's 200 largest cities, a jump from its 2007 ranking of 171. Jakarta has grown more rapidly than <a href="/wiki/Kuala_Lumpur" title="Kuala Lumpur">Kuala Lumpur</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beijing (page does not exist)">Beijing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bangkok" title="Bangkok">Bangkok</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p>Established in the fourth century, the city became an important trading port for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kingdom_of_Sunda&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kingdom of Sunda (page does not exist)">Kingdom of Sunda</a>. It was the de facto capital of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dutch_East_Indies&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dutch East Indies (page does not exist)">Dutch East Indies</a> (known as <b>Batavia</b> at that time) and has continued as the capital of Indonesia since the country's independence was declared in 1945.
</p><p>The city is the seat of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=ASEAN&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ASEAN (page does not exist)">ASEAN</a> Secretariat. Jakarta is served by the <a href="/wiki/Soekarno%E2%80%93Hatta_International_Airport" title="Soekarno–Hatta International Airport">Soekarno–Hatta International Airport</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Halim_Perdanakusuma_International_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Halim Perdanakusuma International Airport (page does not exist)">Halim Perdanakusuma International Airport</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tanjung_Priok" title="Tanjung Priok">Tanjung Priok Harbour</a>; it is connected by several <a href="/wiki/Inter-city_rail" title="Inter-city rail">intercity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Commuter_rail" title="Commuter rail">commuter railways</a>, and served by several <a href="/wiki/Bus" title="Bus">bus</a> lines running on reserved <a href="/wiki/Bus_lane" title="Bus lane">busways</a>.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Toc_left&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Toc left (page does not exist)">Template:Toc left</a>
<br style="clear:both;" />
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p>The place that is now called Jakarta has been home to multiple <a href="/w/index.php?title=Human_settlement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Human settlement (page does not exist)">settlements</a> along with their respective names: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sunda_Kelapa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sunda Kelapa (page does not exist)">Sunda Kelapa</a> (397–1527), Jayakarta (1527–1619), Batavia (1619–1949), and Djakarta (1949–1972).
</p><p>Its current name is derived from the word "Jayakarta". The origins of this word lie in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Old_Javanese&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Old Javanese (page does not exist)">Old Javanese</a> and ultimately in the <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> language. "Jayakarta" translates as "victorious deed", "complete act", or "complete victory".
</p><p>Jakarta is nicknamed <i>the Big <a href="/w/index.php?title=Durian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Durian (page does not exist)">Durian</a></i>, the thorny foul-smelling fruit;<sup id="cite_ref-Jakartapost_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jakartapost-6">[5]</a></sup> the city is seen as the Indonesian equivalent of <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a> (the Big Apple).<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[6]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Prasasti_tugu.jpg" title="File:Prasasti tugu.jpg">File:Prasasti tugu.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The 5th century <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tugu_inscription&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tugu inscription (page does not exist)">Tugu inscription</a> discovered in Tugu district, North Jakarta</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-colonial_era">Pre-colonial era</span></h3>
<p>The area in and around modern Jakarta was part of the fourth century <a href="/wiki/Sundanese_people" title="Sundanese people">Sundanese</a> kingdom of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tarumanagara&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tarumanagara (page does not exist)">Tarumanagara</a>, one of the oldest <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indianized_kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indianized kingdoms (page does not exist)">Hindu kingdoms</a> in Indonesia.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[7]</a></sup> Following the decline of Tarumanagara, its territories, including the Jakarta area, became part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kingdom_of_Sunda&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kingdom of Sunda (page does not exist)">Kingdom of Sunda</a>. From 7th to early 13th century port of Sunda is within the sphere of influence of <a href="/wiki/Srivijaya" title="Srivijaya">Srivijaya</a> maritime empire. According to the Chinese source, <i>Chu-fan-chi</i>, written circa 1200, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chou_Ju-kua&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chou Ju-kua (page does not exist)">Chou Ju-kua</a> reported in the early 13th century Srivijaya still ruled Sumatra, the Malay peninsula, and western Java (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Sunda_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sunda Kingdom (page does not exist)">Sunda</a>). The source reports the port of Sunda as strategic and thriving, <a href="/wiki/Black_pepper" title="Black pepper">pepper</a> from Sunda being among the best in quality. The people worked in agriculture and their houses were built on wooden piles.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[8]</a></sup> The harbour area became known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sunda_Kelapa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sunda Kelapa (page does not exist)">Sunda Kelapa</a> and by the fourteenth century, it was a major trading port for Sunda kingdom.
</p><p>The first European fleet, four <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portuguese</a> ships from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malacca&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Malacca (page does not exist)">Malacca</a>, arrived in 1513 when the Portuguese were looking for a route for spices.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[9]</a></sup> The Kingdom of Sunda <a href="/w/index.php?title=Luso_Sundanese_padr%C3%A3o&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Luso Sundanese padrão (page does not exist)">made an alliance treaty</a> with Portugal by allowing the Portuguese to build a port in 1522 in order to defend against the rising power of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sultanate_of_Demak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sultanate of Demak (page does not exist)">Sultanate of Demak</a> from central Java.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-11">[10]</a></sup> In 1527, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fatahillah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fatahillah (page does not exist)">Fatahillah</a>, a Javanese general from Demak attacked and conquered Sunda Kelapa, driving out the Portuguese. Sunda Kelapa was renamed Jayakarta,<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-11">[10]</a></sup> and became a fiefdom of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sultanate_of_Banten&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sultanate of Banten (page does not exist)">Sultanate of Banten</a> which became a major Southeast Asia trading centre.
</p><p>Through the relationship with Prince Jayawikarta from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sultanate_of_Banten&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sultanate of Banten (page does not exist)">Sultanate of Banten</a>, Dutch ships arrived in Jayakarta in 1596. In 1602, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=English_East_India_Company&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="English East India Company (page does not exist)">English East India Company</a>'s first voyage, commanded by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sir_James_Lancaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sir James Lancaster (page does not exist)">Sir James Lancaster</a>, arrived in <a href="/wiki/Aceh" title="Aceh">Aceh</a> and sailed on to Banten where they were allowed to build a trading post. This site became the centre of English trade in Indonesia until 1682.<sup id="cite_ref-RICKLEFSp29_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RICKLEFSp29-12">[11]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jayawikarta is thought to have made trading connections with the English merchants, rivals of the Dutch, by allowing them to build houses directly across from the Dutch buildings in 1615.<sup id="cite_ref-1596to1619_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1596to1619-13">[12]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Colonial_era">Colonial era</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Stadhuis_Batavia,_Jakarta.jpg" title="File:Stadhuis Batavia, Jakarta.jpg">File:Stadhuis Batavia, Jakarta.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The former <i>Stadhuis</i> of Batavia, the seat of Governor General of <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">VOC</a>. The building now serves as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_History_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta History Museum (page does not exist)">Jakarta History Museum</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Old_Town&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Old Town (page does not exist)">Jakarta Old Town</a> area.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Andries_Beeckman_-_The_Castle_of_Batavia.jpg" title="File:Andries Beeckman - The Castle of Batavia.jpg">File:Andries Beeckman - The Castle of Batavia.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Dutch Batavia built in what is now Jakarta, by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Andries_Beeckman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Andries Beeckman (page does not exist)">Andries Beeckman</a> c. 1656</div></div></div>
<p>When relations between Prince Jayawikarta and the Dutch deteriorated, Jayawikarta's soldiers attacked the Dutch fortress. Prince Jayakarta's army and the English were defeated by the Dutch, in part owing to the timely arrival of <a href="/wiki/Jan_Pieterszoon_Coen" title="Jan Pieterszoon Coen">Jan Pieterszoon Coen</a> (J.P. Coen). The Dutch burned the English fort, and forced the English to retreat on their ships. The victory consolidated Dutch power and in 1619 they renamed the city <i>Batavia</i>.
</p><p>Commercial opportunities in the capital of the Dutch colony attracted Indonesian and especially Chinese immigrants. This sudden population increase created burdens on the city. Tensions grew as the colonial government tried to restrict Chinese migration through deportations. Following a revolt, 5,000 Chinese were <a href="/w/index.php?title=1740_Batavia_massacre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1740 Batavia massacre (page does not exist)">massacred</a> by the Dutch and natives on 9&#160;October 1740 and the following year, Chinese inhabitants were moved to <a href="/wiki/Glodok" title="Glodok">Glodok</a> outside the city walls.<sup id="cite_ref-LONELYPLANETp138-139_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LONELYPLANETp138-139-14">[13]</a></sup> The city began to move further south as epidemics in 1835 and 1870 encouraged more people to move far south of the port. The Koningsplein, now <a href="/w/index.php?title=Merdeka_Square,_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Merdeka Square, Jakarta (page does not exist)">Merdeka Square</a> was completed in 1818, the housing park of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Menteng&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Menteng (page does not exist)">Menteng</a> was started in 1913,<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[14]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kebayoran_Baru&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kebayoran Baru (page does not exist)">Kebayoran Baru</a> was the last Dutch-built residential area.<sup id="cite_ref-LONELYPLANETp138-139_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LONELYPLANETp138-139-14">[13]</a></sup> By 1930 Batavia had more than 500,000 inhabitants,<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[15]</a></sup> including 37,067 Europeans.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[16]</a></sup>
</p><p>During World War II, the city was renamed from Batavia to "Jakarta" (short form of Jayakarta) by the Indonesian nationalists after conquering the city from the Dutch in 1942 with the help of the Japanese forces.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[17]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Clarify&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Clarify (page does not exist)">Template:Clarify</a>
</p><p><br style="clear:both;" />
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Independence_era">Independence era</span></h3>
<p>Following World War II, Indonesian Republicans withdrew from <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allied</a>-occupied Jakarta during <a href="/wiki/Indonesian_National_Revolution" title="Indonesian National Revolution">their fight for Indonesian independence</a> and established their capital in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yogyakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yogyakarta (page does not exist)">Yogyakarta</a>. In 1950, once independence was secured, Jakarta was once again made the national capital.<sup id="cite_ref-LONELYPLANETp138-139_14-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LONELYPLANETp138-139-14">[13]</a></sup> Indonesia's founding president, <a href="/wiki/Sukarno" title="Sukarno">Sukarno</a>, envisaged Jakarta as a great international city, and instigated large government-funded projects with openly nationalistic and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Modernist_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Modernist architecture (page does not exist)">modernist architecture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[18]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[19]</a></sup> Projects included a clover-leaf highway, a major boulevard (Jalan MH Thamrin-Sudirman), monuments such as <a href="/wiki/Monas" title="Monas" class="mw-redirect">The National Monument</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hotel_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hotel Indonesia (page does not exist)">Hotel Indonesia</a>, a shopping centre, and a new parliament building. In October 1965, Jakarta was the site of <a href="/w/index.php?title=30_September_Movement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="30 September Movement (page does not exist)">an abortive coup</a> attempt in which 6 top generals were killed, precipitating <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indonesian_killings_of_1965-66&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indonesian killings of 1965-66 (page does not exist)">a violent anti-communist purge</a> in which half-a million people were killed, including many ethnic Chinese,<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[20]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Transition_to_the_New_Order&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Transition to the New Order (page does not exist)">the beginning of Suharto's New Order</a>. A monument stands  <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lubang_Buaya&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lubang Buaya (page does not exist)">where the generals' bodies were dumped</a>.
</p><p>In 1966, Jakarta was declared a "special capital city district" (<i>daerah khusus ibukota</i>), thus gaining a status approximately equivalent to that of a state or province.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[21]</a></sup> Lieutenant General <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ali_Sadikin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ali Sadikin (page does not exist)">Ali Sadikin</a> served as Governor from the mid-60's commencement of the "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Orde_Baru&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Orde Baru (page does not exist)">New Order</a>" through to 1977; he rehabilitated roads and bridges, encouraged the arts, built several hospitals, and a large number of new schools. He also cleared out slum dwellers for new development projects—some for the benefit of the Suharto family<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[23]</a></sup>—and tried to eliminate rickshaws and ban street vendors. He began control of migration to the city in order to stem overcrowding and poverty.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[24]</a></sup> Foreign investment contributed to a real estate boom which changed the face of the city.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[25]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:JalanJenderalSudirmanJakarta.jpg" title="File:JalanJenderalSudirmanJakarta.jpg">File:JalanJenderalSudirmanJakarta.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Jalan Jenderal Sudirman, Jakarta's main avenue and business district.</div></div></div>
<p>The boom ended with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=East_Asian_Financial_Crisis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East Asian Financial Crisis (page does not exist)">1997/98 East Asian Economic crisis</a> putting Jakarta at the centre of violence, protest, and political maneuvering. After 32 years in power, support for <a href="/w/index.php?title=President_Suharto&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="President Suharto (page does not exist)">President Suharto</a> began to wane. Tensions reached a peak in when four students were <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trisakti_shootings&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trisakti shootings (page does not exist)">shot dead</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trisakti_University&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trisakti University (page does not exist)">Trisakti University</a> by security forces; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_riots_of_May_1998&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta riots of May 1998 (page does not exist)">four days of riots and violence</a> ensued that killed an estimated 1,200, and destroyed or damaged 6,000 buildings.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[26]</a></sup> Much of the rioting targeted <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_Indonesian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese Indonesian (page does not exist)">Chinese Indonesians</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[27]</a></sup> Suharto resigned as president, and Jakarta has remained the focal point of democratic change in Indonesia.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[28]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jemaah_Islamiah" title="Jemaah Islamiah" class="mw-redirect">Jemaah Islamiah</a>-connected bombings occurred almost annually in the city between 2000 and 2005,<sup id="cite_ref-LONELYPLANETp138-139_14-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LONELYPLANETp138-139-14">[13]</a></sup> with <a href="/w/index.php?title=2009_Jakarta_bombings&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2009 Jakarta bombings (page does not exist)">another bombing in 2009</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[29]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Administration">Administration</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Kota_or_kotamadya_.28municipalities.29_and_regency_of_Jakarta"><i>Kota</i> or <i>kotamadya</i> (municipalities) and regency of Jakarta</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Jakarta_subdistrict.png" title="File:Jakarta subdistrict.png">File:Jakarta subdistrict.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Map of the municipalities (<i><a href="/wiki/Kotamadya" title="Kotamadya">kotamadya</a></i>) in Jakarta province. Each city is divided into subdistricts (<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kecamatan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kecamatan (page does not exist)">kecamatan</a></i>).</div></div></div>
<p>Officially, Jakarta is not a city, but a <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Indonesia" title="Provinces of Indonesia">province</a> with special status as the capital of <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>. It has a governor (instead of a mayor), and is divided into several sub-regions with their own administrative systems. As a province, the official name of Jakarta is <i>Daerah Khusus Ibukota Jakarta</i> ("Special Capital City District of Jakarta"), which in Indonesian is abbreviated to DKI Jakarta.
</p><p>Jakarta is divided into five <i>kota</i> or <i>kotamadya</i> ("cities" – formerly municipalities), each headed by a mayor – and one <a href="/w/index.php?title=Regencies_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Regencies of Indonesia (page does not exist)">regency</a> (<i>kabupaten</i>) headed by a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Regent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Regent (page does not exist)">regent</a>. In August 2007, Jakarta held its first ever election to choose a governor, whereas previously the city's governors were appointed by the local house of representatives. The poll is part of a country-wide decentralization drive, allowing for direct local elections in several areas.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[30]</a></sup>
</p><p>The cities/municipalities of Jakarta are:
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Central_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Central Jakarta (page does not exist)">Central Jakarta</a> (<i>Jakarta Pusat</i>) is Jakarta's smallest city and home to most of Jakarta's administrative and political centre. It is characterized by large parks and Dutch colonial buildings. Landmarks include the National Monument (<a href="/wiki/Monas" title="Monas" class="mw-redirect">Monas</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Istiqlal_Mosque,_Jakarta" title="Istiqlal Mosque, Jakarta">Istiqlal Mosque, Jakarta</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Cathedral&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Cathedral (page does not exist)">Jakarta Cathedral</a>, and museums.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[31]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=West_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="West Jakarta (page does not exist)">West Jakarta</a> (<i>Jakarta Barat</i>) has the highest concentration of small-scale industries in Jakarta. The area includes Jakarta's Chinatown and Dutch colonial landmarks such as the Chinese Langgam building and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Toko_Merah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Toko Merah (page does not exist)">Toko Merah</a>. West Jakarta contains part of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Old_Town&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Old Town (page does not exist)">Jakarta Old Town</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[32]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Jakarta (page does not exist)">South Jakarta</a> (<i>Jakarta Selatan</i>), originally planned as a satellite city, is now the location of large upscale shopping centres and affluent residential areas. Jakarta Selatan functions as Jakarta's ground water buffer,<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[33]</a></sup> but recently the green belt areas are threatened by new developments. Much of the CBD area of Jakarta is concentrated in Setia Budi, South Jakarta, bordering the Tanah Abang/Sudirman area of Central Jakarta.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=East_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East Jakarta (page does not exist)">East Jakarta</a> (<i>Jakarta Timur</i>) territory is characterized by several industrial sectors erected in this city.<sup id="cite_ref-Jaktim_go_id_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jaktim_go_id-35">[34]</a></sup> Also located in East Jakarta are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Taman_Mini_Indonesia_Indah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Taman Mini Indonesia Indah (page does not exist)">Taman Mini Indonesia Indah</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Halim_Perdanakusuma_International_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Halim Perdanakusuma International Airport (page does not exist)">Halim Perdanakusuma International Airport</a>.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=North_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="North Jakarta (page does not exist)">North Jakarta</a> (<i>Jakarta Utara</i>) is the only city in Jakarta that is bounded by the sea (<a href="/wiki/Java_Sea" title="Java Sea">Java Sea</a>). It is the location of the <a href="/wiki/Tanjung_Priok" title="Tanjung Priok">Tanjung Priok</a> Port. Large-scale and medium-scale industries are concentrated in North Jakarta. North Jakarta contains part of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Old_Town&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Old Town (page does not exist)">Jakarta Old Town</a>, formerly known as Batavia since the 17th century, and was a centre of <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">VOC</a> trade activity in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dutch_East_Indies&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dutch East Indies (page does not exist)">Dutch East Indies</a>. Also located in North Jakarta is Ancol Dreamland (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Taman_Impian_Jaya_Ancol&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Taman Impian Jaya Ancol (page does not exist)">Taman Impian Jaya Ancol</a>), currently the largest integrated tourism area in South East Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[35]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The only regency (<i>kabupaten</i>) of Jakarta is:
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thousand_Islands_(Indonesia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thousand Islands (Indonesia) (page does not exist)">Thousand Islands</a> (<i>Kepulauan Seribu</i>), formerly a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Subdistricts_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Subdistricts of Indonesia (page does not exist)">subdistrict</a> of North Jakarta, is a collection of 105 small islands located on Java Sea. It has a high conservation value because of its unique and special ecosystems. Marine tourism, such as diving, water bicycle, and wind surfing, is the most important touristic activity in this territory. The main transportation between these islands are speed boat or small ferries.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[36]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<center>
<table class="wikitable sortable" style="background:#ffffef; float:center;">

</caption>

<tr style="text-align:right;">

</th>

<td> 21,071 </td>
<td> 2,422
</td></tr></table>
</center>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span></h3>
<p>In September 1945, the government of Jakarta City was changed from the Japanese <i>Djakarta Toku-Betsu Shi</i> into the Jakarta National Administration. This first government was held by a Mayor until the end of 1960 when the office was changed to that of a Governor. The last mayor of Jakarta was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sudiro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sudiro (page does not exist)">Sudiro</a>, until he was replaced by Dr <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sumarno&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sumarno (page does not exist)">Sumarno</a> as Governor of the province (as the city had now become).
</p><p>In 1974, Based on the <i>Act No. 5 of 1974</i> relating to the Fundamentals of Regional Government, Jakarta was confirmed as the capital of Indonesia and one of Indonesia's (then) 26 provinces.<sup id="cite_ref-Statistics_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Statistics-38">[37]</a></sup>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Municipal_finances">Municipal finances</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Welcome_Roundabout.jpg" title="File:Welcome Roundabout.jpg">File:Welcome Roundabout.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Hotel Indonesia Roundabout</div></div></div>
<p>The ability of the regional government to respond to the many problems of Jakarta is constrained by extremely limited finances.  In 2013 the total budget available to the Jakarta regional government was approved at around Rp 50&#160;trillion (about $US 5.2&#160;billion), equivalent to around $US 380 per citizen. Priority areas of spending were listed as education, transport, flood control measures, environment programs, and various types of social spending (such as health and housing).<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Jakarta provincial government, like all other provincial governments in Indonesia, relies on transfers from the central government for the bulk of budget income.  Local (non-central government) sources of revenue are incomes from various taxes such as vehicle ownership and vehicle transfer fees and so on.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>In recent years, the Jakarta provincial government has consistently run a surplus of between 15-20% of total planned spending, largely because of delays in procurement procedures and other inefficiencies in the spending process.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[40]</a></sup> The regular underspending is a matter of frequent public comment but the legal and administrative blockages that cause the underspending problem seem very difficult to overcome.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[41]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; width:40%;">
<caption> Jakarta city finances: 2007 - 2012 (Rp trillion)
</caption>
<tr>
<th>Year
</th>
<th width="70">Revenue
</th>
<th width="70">Expenditure
</th></tr>
<tr style="text-align:center;">
<td>2007 Actual</td>
<td> 18.7  </td>
<td> 18.7
</td></tr>
<tr style="text-align:center;">
<td>2008 Actual</td>
<td> 32.9  </td>
<td> 16.4
</td></tr>
<tr style="text-align:center;">
<td>2009 Actual</td>
<td> 23.7  </td>
<td> 19.6
</td></tr>
<tr style="text-align:center;">
<td>2010 Actual</td>
<td> 26.8  </td>
<td> 21.6
</td></tr>
<tr style="text-align:center;">
<td>2011 Budget</td>
<td> 31.7  </td>
<td> 31.7
</td></tr>
<tr style="text-align:center;">
<td>2012 Budget</td>
<td> 41.3  </td>
<td> 41.3
</td></tr></table>
<p><small>Indonesian Statistics Bureau: <i>Jakarta in Figures</i></small>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography_and_climate">Geography and climate</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h3>
<p>Jakarta is located on the northwest coast of <a href="/wiki/Java" title="Java">Java</a>, at the mouth of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ciliwung_River&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ciliwung River (page does not exist)">Ciliwung River</a> on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Bay&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Bay (page does not exist)">Jakarta Bay</a>, which is an inlet of the <a href="/wiki/Java_Sea" title="Java Sea">Java Sea</a>. Officially, the area of the Jakarta Special District is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of land area and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of sea area.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[42]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thousand_Islands_(Indonesia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thousand Islands (Indonesia) (page does not exist)">Thousand Islands</a>, which are administratively a part of Jakarta, are located in Jakarta Bay, north of the city.
</p><p>Jakarta lies in a low, flat basin, ranged from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> with average elevation <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Above_mean_sea_level&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Above mean sea level (page does not exist)">above sea level</a>;{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} 40% of Jakarta, particularly the northern areas, is below sea level,<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[43]</a></sup> while the southern parts are comparatively hilly. Rivers flow from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Puncak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Puncak (page does not exist)">Puncak</a> highlands to the south of the city, across the city northwards towards the Java Sea; the most important<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Clarify&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Clarify (page does not exist)">Template:Clarify</a> is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ciliwung_River&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ciliwung River (page does not exist)">Ciliwung River</a>, which divides the city into the western and eastern principalities. Other rivers include the Pesanggrahan, and Sunter.
</p><p>All these rivers, combined with the wet season rains and insufficient drainage due to clogging, make Jakarta prone to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Flooding_in_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Flooding in Jakarta (page does not exist)">flooding</a>. Moreover, Jakarta is sinking about 5 to 10 centimeters each year, even up to 20 centimeters in the northern coastal areas. To help cope with the threat from the sea, the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Netherlands</a> will give $4&#160;million for a feasibility study to build a <a href="/wiki/Levee" title="Levee">dike</a> around Jakarta Bay. The ring dike will be equipped with a pumping system and retention areas to defend against seawater. Additionally, the dike will function as a toll road. The project will be built by 2025.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[44]</a></sup> In January 2014, Central Government agreed to build 2 dams in Ciawi, Bogor and a 1.2 kilometers tunnel from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ciliwung_River&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ciliwung River (page does not exist)">Ciliwung River</a> to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cisadane_River&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cisadane River (page does not exist)">Cisadane River</a> to ease Jakarta floods. Construction costs will be paid by Central Government, but land acquisitions is responsibility of Jakarta Authority.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Wide_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Wide image (page does not exist)">Template:Wide image</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<p>Jakarta has a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tropical_monsoon_climate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tropical monsoon climate (page does not exist)">tropical monsoon climate</a> (<i>Am</i>)<sup id="cite_ref-Climate-Data.org_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Climate-Data.org-47">[46]</a></sup> according to the <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a> system. Despite being located relatively close to the equator, the city has distinct <a href="/wiki/Wet_season" title="Wet season">wet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dry_season" title="Dry season">dry</a> seasons. The wet season in Jakarta covers the majority of the year, running from November through June. The remaining four months forms the city’s dry season. Located in the western part of Java, Jakarta’s wet season rainfall peak is January with average monthly rainfall of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, and its dry season low point is September with a monthly average of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Weather_box&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Weather box (page does not exist)">Template:Weather box</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<p>As the economic and political capital of Indonesia, Jakarta attracts many domestic immigrants who bring their various languages, dialects, foods and customs.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Keong_Emas.jpg" title="File:Keong Emas.jpg">File:Keong Emas.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Golden Snail (Keong Emas), established in the 1970s during the New Order era, is an IMAX theatre located in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Taman_Mini_Indonesia_Indah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Taman Mini Indonesia Indah (page does not exist)">Taman Mini Indonesia Indah</a>, East Jakarta.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Festival_beach_Ancol_Jakarta.jpg" title="File:Festival beach Ancol Jakarta.jpg">File:Festival beach Ancol Jakarta.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Festival Beach in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ancol_Dreamland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ancol Dreamland (page does not exist)">Ancol Dreamland</a>, North Jakarta.</div></div></div>
<p>The "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Betawi_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Betawi people (page does not exist)">Betawi</a>" (<i>Orang Betawi</i>, or "people of Batavia") are the descendants of the people living in and around <a href="/wiki/Batavia,_Dutch_East_Indies" title="Batavia, Dutch East Indies" class="mw-redirect">Batavia</a> and recognized as an ethnic group from around the 18th–19th century. The Betawi people are mostly descended from various Southeast-Asian ethnic groups brought or attracted to Batavia to meet labor needs, and include people from different parts of <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[47]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Betawi_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Betawi language (page does not exist)">language</a> and Betawi culture are distinct from those of the <a href="/wiki/Sundanese_people" title="Sundanese people">Sundanese</a> or <a href="/wiki/Javanese_people" title="Javanese people">Javanese</a>, forming itself as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Language_island&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Language island (page does not exist)">language island</a> in the surrounding area. The language is mostly based on the East <a href="/w/index.php?title=Old_Malay&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Old Malay (page does not exist)">Malay</a> dialect and enriched by <a href="/wiki/Loan_word" title="Loan word" class="mw-redirect">loan words</a> from Dutch, Portuguese, Sundanese, Javanese, Chinese, and Arabic. Nowadays, the Jakarta dialect (Bahasa Jakarta), used as a street language by people in Jakarta, is loosely based on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Betawi_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Betawi language (page does not exist)">Betawi language</a>.
Betawi arts have a low profile in Jakarta, and most Betawi have moved to the suburbs of Jakarta, displaced by new migrants. It is easier to find Java- or Minang-based wedding ceremonies rather than Betawi weddings in Jakarta. 
It is easier to find Javanese Gamelan instead of <i>Gambang Kromong</i> (a mixture between Betawi and Chinese music) or <i>Tanjidor</i> (a mixture between Betawi and Portuguese music) or <i>Marawis</i> (a mixture between Betawi and Yaman music). However, some festivals such as the <i>Jalan Jaksa Festival</i> or <i>Kemang Festival</i> include efforts to preserve Betawi arts by inviting artists to give performances.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p>There has been a significant <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_Indonesian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese Indonesian (page does not exist)">Chinese</a> community in Jakarta for many centuries. The Chinese in Jakarta traditionally reside around old urban areas, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pinangsia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pinangsia (page does not exist)">Pinangsia</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pluit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pluit (page does not exist)">Pluit</a> and <a href="/wiki/Glodok" title="Glodok">Glodok</a> (Jakarta Chinatown) areas. They also can be found in old <a href="/wiki/Chinatown" title="Chinatown">chinatowns</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Senen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Senen (page does not exist)">Senen</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jatinegara&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jatinegara (page does not exist)">Jatinegara</a>. Officially, they make up 6% of the Jakartan population, although this number may be under-reported.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-50">[49]</a></sup> Chinese culture also had influenced Betawi culture, such as the popularity of Chinese cakes and sweets, <a href="/wiki/Firecracker" title="Firecracker">firecrackers</a>, to Betawi wedding attire that demonstrates Chinese and Arab influences.
</p><p>Jakarta has several performing art centres, such as the classical concert hall Aula Simfonia Jakarta in Kemayoran, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Taman_Ismail_Marzuki&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Taman Ismail Marzuki (page does not exist)">Taman Ismail Marzuki</a> (TIM) art centre in Cikini, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gedung_Kesenian_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gedung Kesenian Jakarta (page does not exist)">Gedung Kesenian Jakarta</a> near Pasar Baru, Balai Sarbini in Plaza Semanggi area, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bentara_Budaya_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bentara Budaya Jakarta (page does not exist)">Bentara Budaya Jakarta</a> in Palmerah area, <i>Pasar Seni</i> (Art Market) in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ancol_Dreamland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ancol Dreamland (page does not exist)">Ancol</a>, and traditional Indonesian art performances at the pavilions of some provinces in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Taman_Mini_Indonesia_Indah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Taman Mini Indonesia Indah (page does not exist)">Taman Mini Indonesia Indah</a>. Traditional music is often found at high-class hotels, including <a href="/wiki/Wayang" title="Wayang">Wayang</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gamelan" title="Gamelan">Gamelan</a> performances. Javanese <a href="/wiki/Wayang#Wayang_topeng_or_wayang_gedog_or_wayang_wong" title="Wayang">Wayang Orang</a> performances can be found at Wayang Orang Bharata theater near Senen bus terminal. As the nation's largest city and capital, Jakarta has lured much national and regional talent who hope to find a greater audience and more opportunities for success.
</p><p>Jakarta hosts several prestigious art and culture festivals, and exhibitions, such as the annual <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_International_Film_Festival&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta International Film Festival (page does not exist)">Jakarta International Film Festival</a> (JiFFest), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_International_Java_Jazz_Festival&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta International Java Jazz Festival (page does not exist)">Jakarta International Java Jazz Festival</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Fashion_Week&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Fashion Week (page does not exist)">Jakarta Fashion Week</a>, Jakarta Fashion &amp; Food Festival (JFFF), Jakarta Fair, Indonesia Creative Products and Jakarta Arts and Crafts exhibition. Flona Jakarta is a flora-and-fauna exhibition, held annually in August at Lapangan Banteng Park, featuring flowers, plant nurseries, and pets. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Fair&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Fair (page does not exist)">Jakarta Fair</a> is held annually from mid-June to mid-July to celebrate the anniversary of the city and is largely centred around a trade fair. However this month-long fair also features entertainment, including arts and music performances by local bands and musicians.
</p><p>Several foreign art and culture centres are also established in Jakarta, and mainly serve to promote culture and language through learning centres, libraries, and art galleries. Among these foreign art and cultural centres are <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Confucius_Institute&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Confucius Institute (page does not exist)">Confucius Institute</a>, <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Netherlands</a> Erasmus Huis, UK <a href="/wiki/British_Council" title="British Council">British Council</a>, France Centre Culturel Français, Germany <a href="/wiki/Goethe-Institut" title="Goethe-Institut">Goethe-Institut</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japan_Foundation" title="Japan Foundation">Japan Foundation</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru" title="Jawaharlal Nehru">Jawaharlal Nehru</a> <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">Indian</a> Cultural Centre.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Museums">Museums</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Museum_Nasional_Indonesia.jpg" title="File:Museum Nasional Indonesia.jpg">File:Museum Nasional Indonesia.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Museum_(Indonesia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Museum (Indonesia) (page does not exist)">National Museum</a> of Indonesia in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Central_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Central Jakarta (page does not exist)">Central Jakarta</a></div></div></div>
<p>The museums in Jakarta cluster around the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Central_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Central Jakarta (page does not exist)">Central Jakarta</a> Merdeka Square area, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Old_Town&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Old Town (page does not exist)">Jakarta Old Town</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Taman_Mini_Indonesia_Indah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Taman Mini Indonesia Indah (page does not exist)">Taman Mini Indonesia Indah</a>.
</p><p>The Jakarta Old Town contains museums that are former institutional buildings of Colonial Batavia. Some of these museums are: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_History_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta History Museum (page does not exist)">Jakarta History Museum</a> (former City Hall of Batavia), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wayang_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wayang Museum (page does not exist)">Wayang Museum</a> (Puppet Museum) (former Church of Batavia), the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fine_Art_and_Ceramic_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fine Art and Ceramic Museum (page does not exist)">Fine Art and Ceramic Museum</a> (former Court House of Justice of Batavia), the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maritime_Museum_(Indonesia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maritime Museum (Indonesia) (page does not exist)">Maritime Museum</a> (former <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sunda_Kelapa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sunda Kelapa (page does not exist)">Sunda Kelapa</a> warehouse), Bank Indonesia Museum (former Javasche Bank), and Bank Mandiri Museum (former <i>Nederlandsche Handels Maatschappij</i>).
Several museums clustered in central Jakarta around the Merdeka Square area include: <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Museum_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Museum of Indonesia (page does not exist)">National Museum of Indonesia</a> (also known as <i>Gedung Gajah</i> ("the Elephant Building"), <a href="/wiki/Monas" title="Monas" class="mw-redirect">Monas</a> (National Monument), Istiqlal Islamic Museum in Istiqlal Mosque, Jakarta, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Cathedral&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Cathedral (page does not exist)">Jakarta Cathedral</a> Museum on the second floor of Jakarta Cathedral. Also in the central Jakarta area is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Taman_Prasasti_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Taman Prasasti Museum (page does not exist)">Taman Prasasti Museum</a> (former cemetery of Batavia), and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Textile_Museum_(Jakarta)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Textile Museum (Jakarta) (page does not exist)">Textile Museum</a> in Tanah Abang area.
The recreational area of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Taman_Mini_Indonesia_Indah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Taman Mini Indonesia Indah (page does not exist)">Taman Mini Indonesia Indah</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=East_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East Jakarta (page does not exist)">East Jakarta</a> contains fourteen museums, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indonesia_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indonesia Museum (page does not exist)">Indonesia Museum</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Purna_Bhakti_Pertiwi_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Purna Bhakti Pertiwi Museum (page does not exist)">Purna Bhakti Pertiwi Museum</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Asmat_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Asmat Museum (page does not exist)">Asmat Museum</a>, Bayt al-Qur'an Islamic Museum, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pusaka&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pusaka (page does not exist)">Pusaka</a> (heirloom) Museum, and other science-based museum such as Research &amp; Technology Information Centre, Komodo Indonesian Fauna Museum, Insect Museum, Petrol and Gas Museum, plus the Transportation Museum.
</p><p>Other museums are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Satriamandala_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Satriamandala Museum (page does not exist)">Satria Mandala Military Museum</a>, Museum <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sumpah_Pemuda&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sumpah Pemuda (page does not exist)">Sumpah Pemuda</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lubang_Buaya&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lubang Buaya (page does not exist)">Lubang Buaya</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gado-gado_in_Jakarta.JPG" title="File:Gado-gado in Jakarta.JPG">File:Gado-gado in Jakarta.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Gado-gado" title="Gado-gado">Gado-gado</a> is a popular food in Jakarta.</div></div></div>
<p>Jakarta has a vast range of food available at hundreds of eating complexes located all over the city, from modest street-side foodstalls and traveling vendors to the high-class expensive restaurants. One of the most popular local dishes in Jakarta is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soto_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soto (food) (page does not exist)">Soto</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Betawi_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Betawi people (page does not exist)">Betawi</a>, which is a cow milk or coconut milk broth with beef tendons, intestines, <a href="/wiki/Tripe" title="Tripe">tripe</a>. However since Jakarta is regarded as the 'melting-pot' and a miniature of Indonesia, many traditional food from other regions of Indonesia can be easily found in Jakarta. For example, traditional <a href="/w/index.php?title=Minangkabau_cuisine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Minangkabau cuisine (page does not exist)">Padang</a> restaurants and low-budget <a href="/w/index.php?title=Javanese_cuisine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Javanese cuisine (page does not exist)">Javanese</a> <i>Warteg</i> (<i>Warung Tegal</i>) foodstalls are ubiquitous in the capital. Next to a myriad of selections of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indonesian_Cuisine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indonesian Cuisine (page does not exist)">Indonesian food</a> and regional specialties from all over Indonesia, there is also international food, especially <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Cuisine" title="Chinese Cuisine" class="mw-redirect">Chinese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Cuisine" title="Japanese Cuisine" class="mw-redirect">Japanese</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Korean_Cuisine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Korean Cuisine (page does not exist)">Korean</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thai_food" title="Thai food" class="mw-redirect">Thai</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Cuisine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian Cuisine (page does not exist)">Indian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_the_United_States" title="Cuisine of the United States">American</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=French_Cuisine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="French Cuisine (page does not exist)">French</a>, Middle Eastern, and modern fusion food.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[50]</a></sup>  The other popular foods include: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kerak_Telor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kerak Telor (page does not exist)">kerak telor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gado-gado" title="Gado-gado">gado-gado</a>, <a href="/wiki/Satay" title="Satay">sate</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nasi_goreng&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nasi goreng (page does not exist)">nasi goreng</a> and kue cucur.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Merdeka_Square_Monas_News_Van.JPG" title="File:Merdeka Square Monas News Van.JPG">File:Merdeka Square Monas News Van.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Metro_TV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Metro TV (page does not exist)">Metro TV</a> news van parking in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Merdeka_Square,_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Merdeka Square, Jakarta (page does not exist)">Merdeka Square, Jakarta</a></div></div></div>
<p>Daily newspapers in Jakarta include
</p>
<ul>
<li> Chinese language national newspaper: <i>Indonesia Shang Bao</i>
</li>
<li> English language national newspaper: <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Jakarta_Post&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Jakarta Post (page does not exist)">The Jakarta Post</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Jakarta_Globe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Jakarta Globe (page does not exist)">The Jakarta Globe</a></i>
</li>
<li> Indonesian language national newspaper: <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kompas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kompas (page does not exist)">Kompas</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Koran_Tempo" title="Koran Tempo">Koran Tempo</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Media_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Media Indonesia (page does not exist)">Media Indonesia</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Seputar_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Seputar Indonesia (page does not exist)">Seputar Indonesia</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Republika_(Indonesian_newspaper)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Republika (Indonesian newspaper) (page does not exist)">Republika</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Suara_Pembaruan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Suara Pembaruan (page does not exist)">Suara Pembaruan</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Suara_Karya&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Suara Karya (page does not exist)">Suara Karya</a></i>, <i>Sinar Harapan</i>, <i>Indo Pos</i>, <i>Jurnal Nasional</i>,  <i>Harian Pelita</i>
</li>
<li> Business newspaper: <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bisnis_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bisnis Indonesia (page does not exist)">Bisnis Indonesia</a></i>, <i>Investor Daily</i>, <i>Kontan</i>, <i>Harian Neraca</i>.
</li>
<li> Indonesian language local (Jakarta) newspaper: <i>Pos Kota</i>, <i>Warta Kota</i>, <i>Koran Jakarta</i>, <i>Berita Kota</i>,
</li>
<li> Sport newspaper: <i>Top Skor</i>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Television stations include:
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Public_broadcaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Public broadcaster (page does not exist)">Public broadcaster</a>:<sup id="cite_ref-e-penyiaran.kominfo_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-e-penyiaran.kominfo-52">[51]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=TVRI&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="TVRI (page does not exist)">TVRI</a>
</li>
<li> Private national television: <a href="/w/index.php?title=TPI_(Indonesia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="TPI (Indonesia) (page does not exist)">MNC TV</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=RCTI&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="RCTI (page does not exist)">RCTI</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Metro_TV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Metro TV (page does not exist)">Metro TV</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indosiar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indosiar (page does not exist)">Indosiar</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=ANTV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ANTV (page does not exist)">ANTV</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=SCTV_(Indonesia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="SCTV (Indonesia) (page does not exist)">SCTV</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trans_TV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trans TV (page does not exist)">Trans TV</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=TV_ONE_(Indonesia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="TV ONE (Indonesia) (page does not exist)">tvOne</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trans_7&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trans 7 (page does not exist)">Trans 7</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Global_TV_(Indonesia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Global TV (Indonesia) (page does not exist)">Global TV</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kompas_TV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kompas TV (page does not exist)">Kompas TV</a>.
</li>
<li> Local television: B Channel, JakTV, O Channel, Elshinta TV, Daai TV, and NET.
</li>
<li> Cable television: First Media, <a href="/w/index.php?title=TelkomVision&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="TelkomVision (page does not exist)">TelkomVision</a>
</li>
<li> Satellite television: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indovision&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indovision (page does not exist)">Indovision</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=TelkomVision&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="TelkomVision (page does not exist)">TelkomVision</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Okevision&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Okevision (page does not exist)">Okevision</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aora_TV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aora TV (page does not exist)">Aora TV</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yes_TV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yes TV (page does not exist)">Yes TV</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Many TV stations are analog <a href="/wiki/PAL" title="PAL">PAL</a>, but some are now are converting to digital signals using <a href="/w/index.php?title=DVB-T2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="DVB-T2 (page does not exist)">DVB-T2</a> following government plan to <a href="/wiki/Digital_television" title="Digital television">digital television</a> migration.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>Radio:
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Public_broadcaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Public broadcaster (page does not exist)">Public broadcaster</a>:<sup id="cite_ref-e-penyiaran.kominfo_52-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-e-penyiaran.kominfo-52">[51]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Radio_Republik_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Radio Republik Indonesia (page does not exist)">RRI</a>.
</li>
<li> Investment and Finance Radio: [Radio Finance Indonesia]
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy.2C_governance_and_infrastructure">Economy, governance and infrastructure</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bank_Indonesia_headquarters.jpg" title="File:Bank Indonesia headquarters.jpg">File:Bank Indonesia headquarters.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bank Indonesia (page does not exist)">Bank Indonesia</a> headquarters. Jakarta's economy depends highly on service sectors, including financial, banking and trading sector.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Jakarta's economy depends heavily on financial service, trade, and manufacturing. Industries in Jakarta include electronics, automotive, chemicals, mechanical engineering and biomedical sciences manufacturing.
</p><p>The economic growth of Jakarta in 2007 was 6.44% up from 5.95% the previous year, with the growth in the transportation and communication (15.25%), construction (7.81%) and trade, hotel and restaurant sectors (6.88%).<sup id="cite_ref-Statistics_38-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Statistics-38">[37]</a></sup> In 2007, GRP (Gross Regional Domestic Product) was Rp. 566&#160;trillion (around $US 56&#160;billion). The largest contributions to GDRP were by finance, ownership and business services (29%); trade, hotel and restaurant sector (20%), and manufacturing industry sector (16%).<sup id="cite_ref-Statistics_38-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Statistics-38">[37]</a></sup> In 2007, the increase in per capita GRDP of DKI Jakarta inhabitants was 11.6% compared to the previous year<sup id="cite_ref-Statistics_38-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Statistics-38">[37]</a></sup>
</p><p>Both GRDP by at current market price and GRDP by at 2000 constant price in 2007 for the Municipality of Central Jakarta (Jakarta Pusat), which was Rp 146 million and Rp 81&#160;million, was higher than other municipalities in DKI Jakarta.<sup id="cite_ref-Statistics_38-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Statistics-38">[37]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Governance">Governance</span></h3>
<p>A new law in 2007 forbids the giving of money to beggars, buskers and hawkers, bans squatter settlements on river banks and highways, and prohibits spitting and smoking on public transportation. Unauthorized people cleaning car windscreens and taking tips for directing traffic at intersections will also be penalized. Critics of the new legislation claim that such laws will be difficult to enforce and it tends to ignore the desperate poverty of many of the capital's inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[53]</a></sup>
</p><p>Copying an idea implemented in Singapore's Orchard Road, in 2011, the Jakarta administration said that it would restrict on-street parking on Jl Hayam Wuruk (Haram Wuruk St) and Jl Gajah Mada in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Central_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Central Jakarta (page does not exist)">Central Jakarta</a>. It said it would also remove illegal vendors and beggars from pavements and streets in the area.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[54]</a></sup>  In practice, these measures have only been partially successful.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_supply">Water supply</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Two private companies, PALYJA and Aetra, provide piped water supply in the western and eastern half of Jakarta respectively under 25-year concession contracts signed in 1998. A public asset holding company called PAM Jaya owns the infrastructure. 80% of the water distributed in Jakarta comes through the West Tarum Canal system from Jatiluhur reservoir on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Citarum_River&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Citarum River (page does not exist)">Citarum River</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> southeast of the city. Water supply had been privatized by government of then President Suharto in 1998 to the French company <a href="/w/index.php?title=Suez_Environnement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Suez Environnement (page does not exist)">Suez Environnement</a> and the British company <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thames_Water&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thames Water (page does not exist)">Thames Water</a> International. Both foreign companies subsequently sold their concessions to Indonesian companies. Customer growth in the 7 first years of the concessions had been lower than before, despite substantial inflation-adjusted tariff increases during this period. In 2005 tariffs were frozen, leading the private water companies to cut down on investments.
</p><p>According to PALYJA in its western half of the concession the service coverage ratio increased substantially from 34% in 1998 to 59% in 2007 and 65% in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-PALYJA_figures_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PALYJA_figures-56">[55]</a></sup> According to data by the Jakarta Water Supply Regulatory Body, access in the eastern half of the city served by PTJ increased from about 57% in 1998 to about 67% in 2004, but stagnated after that.<sup id="cite_ref-Iwan_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Iwan-57">[56]</a></sup> However, other sources cite much lower access figures for piped water supply to houses, excluding access provided through public hydrants: One study estimated access as low as 25% in 2005,<sup id="cite_ref-HDR_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HDR-58">[57]</a></sup> while another source estimates it to be as low as 18.5% in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-KRuHA_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KRuHA-59">[58]</a></sup> Those without access to piped water supply get water mostly from wells that are often salty and polluted with bacteria.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demography">Demography</span></h2>
<table class="toccolours" style="float:right; width:420px; margin-left: 1em; margin-bottom: 1ex;">

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<table>

<tr>
<th style="background:#efefef;"> Year

<tr>
<td> 1870 </td>
<td style="text-align:right;"> 65,000

<tr>
<td> 1875 </td>
<td style="text-align:right;"> 99,100
