</p>
</td></tr></table>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Bar_box&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Bar box (page does not exist)">Template:Bar box</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Bar_box&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Bar box (page does not exist)">Template:Bar box</a>
The 2010 census counted some 9.58&#160;million people, well above all government estimates.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[59]</a></sup>  The area of DKI Jakarta is 662.33&#160;km<sup>2</sup>, suggesting a population density of 14,464 people/km<sup>2</sup> as the ninth largest urban population density in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[60]</a></sup> Inwards immigration tended to negate the effect of family planning programs.<sup id="cite_ref-Statistics_38-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Statistics-38">[37]</a></sup> The population has risen from 1.2&#160;million in 1960 to 8.8&#160;million in 2004, counting only its legal residents.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>The population of Greater Jakarta (<a href="/wiki/Jabodetabek" title="Jabodetabek">Jabodetabek</a> Region) is 28,019,545.<sup id="cite_ref-Census_2010_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census_2010-62">[61]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Landmarks">Landmarks</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Istiqlal_Mosque_Monas.jpg" title="File:Istiqlal Mosque Monas.jpg">File:Istiqlal Mosque Monas.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Istiqlal Mosque, Jakarta with Cathedral in the background.</div></div></div>
<p>Most of Jakarta's landmarks, monuments and statues were built during <a href="/wiki/Sukarno" title="Sukarno">Sukarno</a> era around the 1960s and completed in Suharto era, while some are the colonial Dutch East Indies heritage. Near the <a href="/wiki/National_Monument_(Indonesia)" title="National Monument (Indonesia)">national monument</a> stands a <a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">Mahabharata</a> themed Arjuna Wijaya chariot statue and fountain. Further south through Jalan Thamrin, the main avenue of Jakarta, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Selamat_Datang_Monument&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Selamat Datang Monument (page does not exist)"><i>Selamat Datang</i> monument</a> stands on the fountain in the centre of  <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hotel_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hotel Indonesia (page does not exist)">Hotel Indonesia</a> <a href="/wiki/Roundabout" title="Roundabout">roundabout</a>. Other landmarks include the <a href="/wiki/Istiqlal_Mosque,_Jakarta" title="Istiqlal Mosque, Jakarta">Istiqlal Mosque, Jakarta</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Cathedral&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Cathedral (page does not exist)">Jakarta Cathedral</a> and Immanuel Church. The former <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_History_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta History Museum (page does not exist)">Batavia Stadhuis</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Old_Town&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Old Town (page does not exist)">Jakarta Old Town</a> is also the city's landmark. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wisma_46&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wisma 46 (page does not exist)">Wisma 46</a> building in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Central_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Central Jakarta (page does not exist)">Central Jakarta</a> is currently the highest building in Jakarta and Indonesia.
</p><p>Some of statues and monuments in Jakarta are nationalist, such as the <a href="/wiki/West_Irian" title="West Irian" class="mw-redirect">West Irian</a> Liberation monument. Several <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Hero_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Hero of Indonesia (page does not exist)">Indonesian national heroes</a> are commemorated in statues, such as <a href="/wiki/Diponegoro" title="Diponegoro">Diponegoro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kartini" title="Kartini">Kartini</a> statues in Merdeka Square, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sudirman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sudirman (page does not exist)">Sudirman</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mohammad_Husni_Thamrin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mohammad Husni Thamrin (page does not exist)">Thamrin</a> statues located in each respectable avenues, also <a href="/wiki/Sukarno" title="Sukarno">Sukarno</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Hatta" title="Mohammad Hatta">Hatta</a> statues in Proclamation Monument also on the entrance of Soekarno–Hatta International Airport.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h2>
<p>Most of the visitors attracted to Jakarta are domestic tourists from all over Indonesia. As the gateway of Indonesia, Jakarta often serves as the stop-over for foreign visitors on their way to Indonesian popular tourist destinations such as <a href="/wiki/Bali" title="Bali">Bali</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yogyakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yogyakarta (page does not exist)">Yogyakarta</a>.
Other than attracted to monuments, landmarks, and museums around <a href="/w/index.php?title=Merdeka_Square,_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Merdeka Square, Jakarta (page does not exist)">Merdeka square</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Old_Town&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Old Town (page does not exist)">Jakarta Old Town</a>, tourist attractions include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Taman_Mini_Indonesia_Indah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Taman Mini Indonesia Indah (page does not exist)">Taman Mini Indonesia Indah</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ragunan_Zoo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ragunan Zoo (page does not exist)">Ragunan Zoo</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sunda_Kelapa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sunda Kelapa (page does not exist)">Sunda Kelapa</a> old port and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ancol_Dreamland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ancol Dreamland (page does not exist)">Ancol Dreamland</a> complex on Jakarta Bay, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ancol_Dreamland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ancol Dreamland (page does not exist)">Dunia Fantasi</a> theme park, Sea World, Atlantis Water Adventure, and Gelanggang Samudra.
</p><p>Tourism is contributing a growing amount of income to the city. In 2012, the tourism sector contributed 2.6 trillion rupiah (US$268.5 million) to the city’s total direct income of 17.83 trillion rupiah, a 17.9 per cent increase over 2011. Tourism stakeholders are expecting greater marketing of the Jakarta as a tourism destination.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[62]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Shopping">Shopping</span></h2>
<p>Jakarta is a shopping hub in the nation also one of the best places to shop in <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_East_Asia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South East Asia (page does not exist)">South East Asia</a>. The city has numerous <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_malls_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of malls in Indonesia (page does not exist)">shopping malls</a> and traditional markets. The annual "Jakarta Great Sale" is held every year on June and July to celebrate Jakarta's anniversary with about 73 participating shopping centres in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[63]</a></sup>
</p><p>Malls such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plaza_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plaza Indonesia (page does not exist)">Plaza Indonesia</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plaza_Senayan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plaza Senayan (page does not exist)">Plaza Senayan</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Senayan_City&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Senayan City (page does not exist)">Senayan City</a> provides numerous selections of luxury brands. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mall_Taman_Anggrek&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mall Taman Anggrek (page does not exist)">Mall Taman Anggrek</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pondok_Indah_Mall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pondok Indah Mall (page does not exist)">Pondok Indah Mall</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mal_Kelapa_Gading&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mal Kelapa Gading (page does not exist)">Mal Kelapa Gading</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Central_Park_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Central Park Jakarta (page does not exist)">Central Park Jakarta</a> cater high-street brands such as UK's <a href="/wiki/Topshop" title="Topshop">Topshop</a> and Europe's <a href="/wiki/Zara_(retailer)" title="Zara (retailer)">Zara</a> <sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[64]</a></sup>
</p><p>United Kingdom's number one department store, Debenhams has 3 outlets in the city, the first one on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Senayan_City&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Senayan City (page does not exist)">Senayan City</a>, Supermall Karawaci and Lippo Mall Kemang Village. Japan's international <a href="/wiki/Sogo" title="Sogo">Sogo</a> department store has about 6 department stores which spread around shopping malls in the city. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Seibu_Department_Stores&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Seibu Department Stores (page does not exist)">Seibu</a> flagship store is located on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grand Indonesia (page does not exist)">Grand Indonesia Shopping Town</a>. And French luxury department store, <a href="/wiki/Galeries_Lafayette" title="Galeries Lafayette">Galeries Lafayette</a> will open its doors for the first time on South East Asia in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pacific_Place_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pacific Place Jakarta (page does not exist)">Pacific Place Jakarta</a>.
</p><p>Internationally known luxury brands such as <a href="/wiki/Louis_Vuitton" title="Louis Vuitton">Louis Vuitton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bulgari" title="Bulgari">Bulgari</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chanel" title="Chanel">Chanel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gucci" title="Gucci">Gucci</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christian_Louboutin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christian Louboutin (page does not exist)">Christian Louboutin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Balenciaga" title="Balenciaga">Balenciaga</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Giorgio_Armani" title="Giorgio Armani">Giorgio Armani</a> can be easily found on Jakarta's luxury shopping malls.
</p><p>Satrio-Casablanca corridor, 3.5 kilometre-long street that is a new shopping belt in Jakarta.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[65]</a></sup> Many multistorey shopping centres are located here, such as Kuningan City, Mal Ambassador, and Kota Kasablanka. And Satrio-Casablanca's largest shopping centre, Ciputra World Jakarta, will open in 2013.
</p><p>Traditional markets include <a href="/wiki/Blok_M" title="Blok M">Blok M</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tanah_Abang" title="Tanah Abang">Tanah Abang</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Senen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Senen (page does not exist)">Senen</a>, Pasar Baru, <a href="/wiki/Glodok" title="Glodok">Glodok</a>, Mangga Dua, Cempaka Mas, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jatinegara&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jatinegara (page does not exist)">Jatinegara</a>. In Jakarta there are also markets that sells specified collectable items, such as <a href="/wiki/Antique" title="Antique">antique</a> goods in Surabaya Street and gemstones in Rawabening Market.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Parks">Parks</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Monumen_nasional_jakarta.jpg" title="File:Monumen nasional jakarta.jpg">File:Monumen nasional jakarta.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/National_Monument_(Indonesia)" title="National Monument (Indonesia)">National Monument</a> in the centre of Medan Merdeka Park</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Plaza_indonesia.jpg" title="File:Plaza indonesia.jpg">File:Plaza indonesia.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Plaza_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plaza Indonesia (page does not exist)">Plaza Indonesia</a>, the high end shopping centre in Jakarta</div></div></div>
<p>Taman Lapangan Banteng (Buffalo Field Park) is located in Central Jakarta near the <a href="/wiki/Istiqlal_Mosque,_Jakarta" title="Istiqlal Mosque, Jakarta">Istiqlal Mosque, Jakarta</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Cathedral&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Cathedral (page does not exist)">Jakarta Cathedral</a>, and the Jakarta Central Post Office. It is about 4.5 hectares. Initially it was called Waterlooplein of Batavia and functioned as the ceremonial square during the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_Indies" title="Netherlands Indies" class="mw-redirect">Netherlands Indies</a> colonial period. A number of colonial monuments and memorials erected on the square during the colonial period were demolished during the Sukarno era.  The most notable monument in the square is the Monumen Pembebasan Irian Barat (Monument of the Liberation of West Irian). During the 1970s and 1980s the park was used as a bus terminal. In 1993 the park was turned into a public space again.  It has become a recreation place for people and is occasionally also used as an exhibition place or for other events.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[66]</a></sup> The Jakarta Flona (Flora dan Fauna), the flower and decoration plants and pet exhibition, is held in this park around August annually.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Taman_Mini_Indonesia_Indah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Taman Mini Indonesia Indah (page does not exist)">Taman Mini Indonesia Indah</a> (Miniature Park of Indonesia), in <a href="/w/index.php?title=East_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East Jakarta (page does not exist)">East Jakarta</a>, has 10 mini parks. But the most popular is The Bird Park or Aviary
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:TMII_Bird_Park.JPG" title="File:TMII Bird Park.JPG">File:TMII Bird Park.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Spherical cage <a href="/wiki/Aviary" title="Aviary">Bird Park</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Taman_Mini_Indonesia_Indah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Taman Mini Indonesia Indah (page does not exist)">Taman Mini Indonesia Indah</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Taman Suropati is located in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Menteng&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Menteng (page does not exist)">Menteng</a> city subdistrict in Central Jakarta. The park is surrounded by several Dutch colonial buildings. Taman Suropati was known as Burgemeester Bisschopplein during the Dutch colonial time. The park is circular shaped with a surface area of 16,322&#160;m2. There are several modern statues in the park made by artists of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=ASEAN&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ASEAN (page does not exist)">ASEAN</a> countries, which contributes to the nickname of the park <i>"Taman persahabatan seniman ASEAN"</i> ("Park of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=ASEAN&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ASEAN (page does not exist)">ASEAN</a> artists friendship").<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[67]</a></sup> Also located in the Menteng area are the Taman Menteng and Situ Lembang pond parks. The Taman Menteng was built on the former <a href="/w/index.php?title=Persija&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Persija (page does not exist)">Persija</a> soccer Stadium.
</p><p>Taman Monas (Monas Park) or Taman Medan Merdeka (Medan Merdeka Park) is a huge square where the symbol of Jakarta, <a href="/wiki/Monas" title="Monas" class="mw-redirect">Monas</a> or Monumen Nasional (National Monument) is located. The enormous space was created by Dutch Governor General Herman Willem <a href="/w/index.php?title=Daendels&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Daendels (page does not exist)">Daendels</a> (1810) and was originally named Koningsplein (Kings Square). On 10 January 1993, President Soeharto initiated action for the beautification of the square. Several features in the square are a deer park and 33 trees that represents the 33 provinces of Indonesia.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[68]</a></sup>
</p><p>In June 2011, Jakarta has only 10.5 percent Ruang Terbuka Hijau (Green Open Space) and will be added to 13.94 percent Public Green Open Space. Public Parks are include in Public Green Open Space. By 2030, the administration also hope there are 16 percent Private Green Open Space.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[69]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gelora_Bung_Karno_Stadium,_Asia_Cup_2007.jpg" title="File:Gelora Bung Karno Stadium, Asia Cup 2007.jpg">File:Gelora Bung Karno Stadium, Asia Cup 2007.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bung_Karno_Stadium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bung Karno Stadium (page does not exist)">Bung Karno Stadium</a> during soccer match between Indonesia vs South Korea in 2007 AFC <a href="/w/index.php?title=Asian_Cup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Asian Cup (page does not exist)">Asian Cup</a></div></div></div>
<p>Jakarta was host to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=1962_Asian_Games&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1962 Asian Games (page does not exist)">Asian Games in 1962</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[70]</a></sup> host of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Asian_Cup_2007&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Asian Cup 2007 (page does not exist)">Asian Cup 2007</a> beside Malaysia, Thailand and Vietnam,<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[71]</a></sup> and has hosted the regional-scale <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asian_Games" title="Southeast Asian Games">Southeast Asian Games</a> in 1979, 1987 and 1997. In 2011, Jakarta again hosted the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Southeast_Asian_Games&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Southeast Asian Games (page does not exist)">Southeast Asian Games</a>, but this time as co-hosts with <a href="/wiki/Palembang" title="Palembang">Palembang</a>.
</p><p>Jakarta's most popular home football club is <a href="/wiki/Persija_Jakarta" title="Persija Jakarta">Persija</a>, which plays its matches in their home stadium at Bung Karno Stadium. The home match of Persija often draws its large fan – cladded with Persija's typical orange kit – to watch the match in the main stadium. The large spectators flocking to the main stadium usually worsen the traffic congestion in Jakarta. Another premiere division team is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Persitara_Jakarta_Utara&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Persitara Jakarta Utara (page does not exist)">Persitara</a> which plays its matches in the Kamal Muara Stadium in Kamal area.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Jakarta_city_stadium.jpg" title="File:Jakarta city stadium.jpg">File:Jakarta city stadium.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Gelora Bung Karno Stedium area</div></div></div>
<p>The biggest stadium in Jakarta is the <a href="/wiki/Gelora_Bung_Karno_Stadium" title="Gelora Bung Karno Stadium">Gelora Bung Karno Stadium</a> with a capacity of 88,083 seats.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[72]</a></sup> The Senayan sports complex has several sport venues, including the Bung Karno soccer stadium, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Madya_Stadium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Madya Stadium (page does not exist)">Madya Stadium</a>, Istora Senayan, aquatic arena, baseball field, basketball court, badminton court, a shooting range, several indoor and outdoor tennis court and a golf driving range. The Senayan complex was built in 1959 to accommodate the Asian Games in 1962. For basketball, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kelapa_Gading_Sport_Mall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kelapa Gading Sport Mall (page does not exist)">Kelapa Gading Sport Mall</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kelapa_Gading&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kelapa Gading (page does not exist)">Kelapa Gading</a>, North Jakarta, with a capacity of 7,000 seats, is the home arena of the Indonesian national basketball team.
</p><p>The Jakarta <a href="/wiki/Car-Free_Days" title="Car-Free Days">Car-Free Days</a> are held weekly on Sunday on the main avenues of the city, Jalan Sudirman and Jalan Thamrin, from 6&#160;am to 11&#160;am. The briefer Car-Free Day which lasts from only 6&#160;am to 9&#160;am is held on every other Sunday. The event invites local pedestrians to do sports and exercise and have their activities on the streets that are normally full of cars and traffic. Along the road from the Senayan traffic circle on Jalan Sudirman, South Jakarta, to the "Selamat Datang" Monument at the Hotel Indonesia traffic circle on Jalan Thamrin, all the way north to the National Monument in Central Jakarta, cars are cleared out for pedestrians. Morning gymnastics, <a href="/wiki/Calisthenics" title="Calisthenics">calisthenics</a> and aerobic exercises, <a href="/wiki/Futsal" title="Futsal">futsal</a> games, <a href="/wiki/Jogging" title="Jogging">jogging</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bicycling" title="Bicycling" class="mw-redirect">bicycling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Skateboarding" title="Skateboarding">skateboarding</a>, badminton, karate, and on-street library and musical performances take over the roads and the main parks in Jakarta.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[73]</a></sup>
<br style="clear:both;" />
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Jakarta_Car_Free_Day.jpg" title="File:Jakarta Car Free Day.jpg">File:Jakarta Car Free Day.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Jakarta pedestrians, joggers and bicyclists take over the main avenue during Car-Free Day.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:LimoNCP42Bluebird07.jpg" title="File:LimoNCP42Bluebird07.jpg">File:LimoNCP42Bluebird07.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Taxi in Jakarta.</div></div></div>
<p>With 28 million people in the metropolitan area, nearly 10 million vehicles in daily use, and no <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rapid_transit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rapid transit (page does not exist)">rapid transit</a> system<sup id="cite_ref-NYT8413_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT8413-75">[74]</a></sup> Jakarta is strained by transportation problems.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc_20070606_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc_20070606-76">[75]</a></sup> The city suffers a lack of urban public transport services due to prioritized development of road networks, which were mostly designed to accommodate private vehicles.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[76]</a></sup>
Most trips, however, are undertaken by non-motorized transportation (particularly walking) and numerous modes of public or demand-responsive transportation services.<sup id="cite_ref-jica_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jica-78">[77]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable">

<tr>
<th> Transport mode </th>
<th> No. trips ('000) </th>
<th>&#160;% share
</th></tr>
<tr>

</td></tr>

</td></tr>

<td> 100
</td></tr></table>
<p><sup id="cite_ref-SITRAMP_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SITRAMP-79">[78]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Road">Road</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:3in1GatsuViosCorollaAltis.JPG" title="File:3in1GatsuViosCorollaAltis.JPG">File:3in1GatsuViosCorollaAltis.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Some major roads in Jakarta are implementing 3 passengers in a car regulation during rush hours.</div></div></div>
<p>A structured road network had been developed in the early 19th century as a part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Post_Road&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Post Road (page does not exist)">Java Great Post Road</a> by former Governor-General <a href="/w/index.php?title=Daendels&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Daendels (page does not exist)">Daendels</a>, which connects most major cities throughout <a href="/wiki/Java" title="Java">Java</a>. During the following decades, the road network was expanded to a great extent, although it could not keep up with the rapidly increasing numbers of motorized vehicles, resulting in highly congested traffic.
</p><p>A notable feature of Jakarta's present road system is the <a href="/wiki/Toll_road" title="Toll road">toll road</a> network. Composed of an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Inner_Ring_Road&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Inner Ring Road (page does not exist)">inner</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Outer_Ring_Road&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Outer Ring Road (page does not exist)">outer</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ring_road&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ring road (page does not exist)">ring road</a> and five toll roads radiating outwards, the network provides inner as well as outer city connections.
The outer ring road is under construction, but it is largely in use. Six <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Elevated_Toll_Road&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Elevated Toll Road (page does not exist)">elevated toll roads</a> are in tender progress.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>The five radiating toll roads are the:
</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Prof._Dr._Sedyatmo_Toll_Road&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Prof. Dr. Sedyatmo Toll Road (page does not exist)">Prof. Dr. Sedyatmo Toll Road</a> linking to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soekarno-Hatta_International_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soekarno-Hatta International Airport (page does not exist)">Soekarno-Hatta International Airport</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta-Tangerang_Toll_Road&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta-Tangerang Toll Road (page does not exist)">Jakarta-Tangerang Toll Road</a> linking to <a href="/wiki/Tangerang" title="Tangerang">Tangerang</a> and further to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Merak,_Banten&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Merak, Banten (page does not exist)">Merak</a> in the west
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta-Serpong_Toll_Road&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta-Serpong Toll Road (page does not exist)">Jakarta-Serpong Toll Road</a> linking to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Serpong&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Serpong (page does not exist)">Serpong</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Jagorawi_Toll_Road&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jagorawi Toll Road (page does not exist)">Jagorawi Toll Road</a> linking to <a href="/wiki/Bogor" title="Bogor">Bogor</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ciawi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ciawi (page does not exist)">Ciawi</a> in the south
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta-Cikampek_Toll_Road&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta-Cikampek Toll Road (page does not exist)">Jakarta-Cikampek Toll Road</a> linking to <a href="/wiki/Bekasi" title="Bekasi">Bekasi</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cikampek&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cikampek (page does not exist)">Cikampek</a> in the east
</li>
</ul>
<p>Throughout the years, several attempts have been made to reduce traffic congestion on Jakarta’s main arteries. Implemented solutions include a 'three-in-one' rush-hour law, during which cars with fewer than three passengers are prohibited from driving on the main avenues.
Another example is the ban on trucks passing main avenues during the day.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[79]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_road_transportation">Public road transportation</span></h4>
<p>In 1966, an estimated 160 thousand <a href="/wiki/Cycle_rickshaw" title="Cycle rickshaw">pedicabs</a> (<i>becak</i>) operated in the city; as much as 15% of Jakarta's total workforce was engaged in <i>becak</i> driving. In 1971, <i>becak</i> were banned from major roads, and shortly thereafter the government attempted a total ban, which substantially reduced their numbers but did not eliminate them. A campaign to eliminate them succeeded in 1990 and 1991, but during the economic crisis of 1998, some returned amid less effective government attempts to control them.<sup id="cite_ref-azuma2003_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-azuma2003-81">[80]</a></sup>
</p><p>"Auto rickshaws", called <i><a href="/wiki/Auto_rickshaw" title="Auto rickshaw">bajaj</a></i>, provide local transportation in the back streets of some parts of the city. From the early 1940s to 1991 they were a common form of local transportation in the city.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:TransJakarta_Bundaran_HI_1.jpg" title="File:TransJakarta Bundaran HI 1.jpg">File:TransJakarta Bundaran HI 1.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/w/index.php?title=TransJakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="TransJakarta (page does not exist)">TransJakarta</a> bus</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=TransJakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="TransJakarta (page does not exist)">TransJakarta</a> <a href="/wiki/Bus_rapid_transit" title="Bus rapid transit">bus rapid transit</a> service (known as Busway) was developed in the context of development reforms (or <i>reformasi</i>) and used Bogota's <a href="/wiki/TransMilenio" title="TransMilenio">TransMilenio</a> system as a model.<sup id="cite_ref-lo2010_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lo2010-82">[81]</a></sup> Jakarta's first busway line, from <a href="/wiki/Blok_M" title="Blok M">Blok M</a> to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Kota_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Kota Station (page does not exist)">Jakarta Kota</a> opened in January 2004 and as of 14 February 2013, twelve out of fifteen <i>corridors</i> are in use.
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kopaja&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kopaja (page does not exist)">Kopaja</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=MetroMini,_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MetroMini, Jakarta (page does not exist)">MetroMini</a> economy minibus systems also provide important services for Jakarta commuters with numerous routes throughout the city.
</p><p>Although <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Motorcycle_taxi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Motorcycle taxi (page does not exist)">ojeks</a></i> are not an official form of public transport, they can be found throughout Indonesia and in Jakarta. They are especially useful on the crowded urban roads and narrow alleyways, which other vehicles cannot reach. In November 2011, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Taxijek&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Taxijek (page does not exist)">Taxijek</a> was launched in Jakarta. It is essentially a taxi, but with a motorcycle instead of an automobile. Besides a <a href="/wiki/Taximeter" title="Taximeter">taximeter</a> and the company's driver identity card, the passenger has access to a helmet, disposable shower caps to use underneath the helmet and an extra raincoat. Contrary to common ojeks, Taxijeks are allowed to enter <a href="/wiki/Gated_community" title="Gated community">gated communities</a> and they usually charge a lower fare.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[82]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Electronic_Road_Pricing">Electronic Road Pricing</span></h4>
<p>Due to the city's acute gridlock, the Jakarta administration will implement <a href="/wiki/Electronic_Road_Pricing" title="Electronic Road Pricing">Electronic Road Pricing</a> (ERP) in 10 districts: Tanah Abang, Menteng, Setiabudi, Tebet, Matraman, Senen, Gambir, Tambora, Sawah Besar and Taman Sari. The projects will initiate once approved by the Finance Ministry.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[83]</a></sup> The ERP will be implemented in the three-in-one zone and along Jl. Rasuna Said in Kuningan by the first quarter of 2014. Vehicles passing through the ERP areas will be charged Rp 21,072.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[84]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Railways">Railways</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:KRL_Jabotabek_7117_Gambir.jpg" title="File:KRL Jabotabek 7117 Gambir.jpg">File:KRL Jabotabek 7117 Gambir.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/w/index.php?title=KRL_Jabotabek&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="KRL Jabotabek (page does not exist)">KRL Jabotabek</a> commuter train</div></div></div>
<p>As of 2013 plans were underway to invest $4 billion in <a href="/wiki/Mass_transit" title="Mass transit" class="mw-redirect">mass transit</a> over the next few years including commencement of a subway.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT8413_75-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT8413-75">[74]</a></sup>
</p><p>Long-distance railways and local tram services were first introduced during the Dutch colonial era.  While the trams were replaced with buses in the post-colonial era, <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Indonesia" title="Rail transport in Indonesia">long-distance railways</a> continued to connect the city to its neighbouring regions as well as cities throughout <a href="/wiki/Java" title="Java">Java</a>. The surrounding cities of Jakarta are served by <a href="/w/index.php?title=KRL_Jabotabek&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="KRL Jabotabek (page does not exist)">KRL Jabotabek</a>, a mass rapid transit system which serves commuters both in and around Jakarta. The major rail stations are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gambir_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gambir Station (page does not exist)">Gambir</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Kota_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Kota Station (page does not exist)">Jakarta Kota</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jatinegara_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jatinegara Station (page does not exist)">Jatinegara</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pasar_Senen_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pasar Senen Station (page does not exist)">Pasar Senen</a>, Manggarai, and Tanah Abang. During rush hours, the number of passengers greatly exceeds the system's capacity, and crowding is common.
</p><p>There had been plans for a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Monorail&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Monorail (page does not exist)">monorail</a> and part of it was already under construction, but the project stalled in 2004 and was officially abandoned as of 2008, mostly due to a lack of investors to fund it all. The monorail project was relaunched in 2013 and the groundbreaking was done in October 2013<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[85]</a></sup>
</p><p>A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_Mass_Rapid_Transit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta Mass Rapid Transit (page does not exist)">two-line metro (MRT) system</a> is under construction, with a north-south line between Kota and Lebak Bulus; and an east-west line, which will connect to the north-south line at Sawah Besar Station. In the end the JMRT will be a combination of both subways and elevated rails. Preparation works started in April 2012,<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[86]</a></sup> with the first, 15.2&#160;km-long line between Hotel Indonesia and Lebak Bulus, and the north-south line MRT network is scheduled to be operational by 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[87]</a></sup>
The Jakarta Capital City Government had decided to build rail-based mass transits because this type of transport is capable of carrying passengers in large quantities quickly and cheaply.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[88]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Air">Air</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Soekarno-Hatta_International_Airport_Terminal_3_front.JPG" title="File:Soekarno-Hatta International Airport Terminal 3 front.JPG">File:Soekarno-Hatta International Airport Terminal 3 front.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Front view of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soekarno-Hatta_International_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soekarno-Hatta International Airport (page does not exist)">Soekarno-Hatta International Airport</a> Terminal 3.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Soekarno%E2%80%93Hatta_International_Airport" title="Soekarno–Hatta International Airport">Soekarno–Hatta International Airport</a> (CGK) is the main airport serving the greater Jakarta area. The airport is named after the first President of Indonesia, <a href="/wiki/Soekarno" title="Soekarno" class="mw-redirect">Soekarno</a>, and the first vice-president, <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Hatta" title="Mohammad Hatta">Mohammad Hatta</a>. The airport is often called Cengkareng or Soetta by Indonesians. The airport's IATA code, CGK, originates from the name of the Cengkareng locality,<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[89]</a></sup> a district situated to the northwest of the city. It is Indonesia's busiest airport handling over 50 million passengers annually.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[90]</a></sup>  A second airport, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Halim_Perdanakusuma_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Halim Perdanakusuma Airport (page does not exist)">Halim Perdanakusuma Airport</a> (HLP) serves domestic flight of low cost airline,private and VIP/presidential flights.
Other airports in the Jabotabek metropolitan area include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pondok_Cabe_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pondok Cabe Airport (page does not exist)">Pondok Cabe Airport</a> and an airfield on Pulau Panjang, part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thousand_Islands_(Indonesia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thousand Islands (Indonesia) (page does not exist)">Thousand Island archipelago</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Waterway">Waterway</span></h3>
<p>On 6 June 2007, the city administration introduced the Waterway (officially <i>Angkutan Sungai</i>), a new river boat service along the Ciliwung River.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc_20070606_76-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc_20070606-76">[75]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-waterway2_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-waterway2-92">[91]</a></sup> However, because of the large amount of floating garbage which kept jamming the propeller, it is no longer in service. The varying water levels during the dry and wet seasons were also a contributing factor to the close-down.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sea">Sea</span></h3>
<p>Jakarta's main seaport <a href="/w/index.php?title=Port_of_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Port of Jakarta (page does not exist)">Tanjung Priok</a> serves many ferry connections to different parts of Indonesia. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Port_of_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Port of Jakarta (page does not exist)">Tanjung Priok</a> is the largest seaport in Indonesia, with an annual traffic capacity of around 45 million tonnes of cargo and 4,000,000 TEU's.
The port is also an important employer in the area, with more than 18,000 employees who provide services to more than 18,000 ships every year.
The <i>Port of Jakarta</i> has 20 terminals: <a href="/wiki/Cargo" title="Cargo">general cargo</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Container_terminal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Container terminal (page does not exist)">multipurpose terminal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scrap" title="Scrap">scraps terminal</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Passenger&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Passenger (page does not exist)">passenger terminal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bulk_cargo" title="Bulk cargo">dry bulk terminal</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bulk_liquids&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bulk liquids (page does not exist)">liquid bulk terminal</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oil_terminal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oil terminal (page does not exist)">oil terminal</a>,  <a href="/wiki/Chemical" title="Chemical" class="mw-redirect">chemicals terminal</a> and three <a href="/w/index.php?title=Container_terminal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Container terminal (page does not exist)">container terminals</a>, 76 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Berth_(moorings)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Berth (moorings) (page does not exist)">berths</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Quay" title="Quay" class="mw-redirect">quay</a> length of 16,853 metres, a total storage area of 661,822 m<sup>2</sup> and a storage capacity of 401,468 tonnes.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[92]</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2011, Muara Angke Port has been renovated yet with cost Rp130 billion ($14.4 million) in 3 hectares area. Next, Muara Angke Port will be used for public transport port to <a href="/wiki/Thousand_Islands" title="Thousand Islands">Thousand Islands</a>, while Marina <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ancol&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ancol (page does not exist)">Ancol</a> Port will be used as tourist ship port.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[93]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Fakultas_Kedokteran_Universitas_Indonesia.JPG" title="File:Fakultas Kedokteran Universitas Indonesia.JPG">File:Fakultas Kedokteran Universitas Indonesia.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Faculty of Medicine, <a href="/wiki/University_of_Indonesia" title="University of Indonesia">University of Indonesia</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Jakarta is home to a number of universities, of which the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Indonesia" title="University of Indonesia">University of Indonesia</a> is the largest. It is a state-owned university with campuses in Salemba and <a href="/wiki/Depok" title="Depok">Depok</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[94]</a></sup> Jakarta is also home to two other state universities: the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Syarif_Hidayatullah_State_Islamic_University_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Syarif Hidayatullah State Islamic University Jakarta (page does not exist)">Syarif Hidayatullah State Islamic University Jakarta</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=State_University_of_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="State University of Jakarta (page does not exist)">State University of Jakarta</a>. Some major private universities located in Jakarta are: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trisakti_University&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trisakti University (page does not exist)">Trisakti University</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tarumanagara_University&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tarumanagara University (page does not exist)">Tarumanagara University</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Atma_Jaya_University&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Atma Jaya University (page does not exist)">Atma Jaya University</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pelita_Harapan_University&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pelita Harapan University (page does not exist)">Pelita Harapan University</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bina_Nusantara_University&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bina Nusantara University (page does not exist)">Bina Nusantara University</a>.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=STOVIA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="STOVIA (page does not exist)">STOVIA</a> (<i>School tot Opleiding van Indische Artsen</i>) was the first high school in Jakarta, established in 1851.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[95]</a></sup> As the largest city and the capital, Jakarta houses a large number of students from various parts of Indonesia, many of whom reside in dormitories or home-stay residences. For basic education, there are a variety of primary and secondary schools, tagged with public (<i>national</i>), private (<i>national and bi-lingual national plus</i>) and <i>international</i> schools.   Four of the major international schools located in Jakarta are the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gandhi_Memorial_International_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gandhi Memorial International School (page does not exist)">Gandhi Memorial International School</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=IPEKA_International_Christian_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="IPEKA International Christian School (page does not exist)">IPEKA International Christian School</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_International_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta International School (page does not exist)">Jakarta International School</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_International_School,_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British International School, Jakarta (page does not exist)">British International School (BIS)</a>. Other international schools include the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_International_Korean_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta International Korean School (page does not exist)">Jakarta International Korean School</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bina_Bangsa_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bina Bangsa School (page does not exist)">Bina Bangsa School</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakarta_International_Multicultural_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakarta International Multicultural School (page does not exist)">Jakarta International Multicultural School</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[96]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Australian_International_School,_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Australian International School, Indonesia (page does not exist)">Australian International School</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[97]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand_International_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Zealand International School (page does not exist)">New Zealand International School</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[98]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Singapore_International_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Singapore International School (page does not exist)">Singapore International School</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sekolah_Pelita_Harapan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sekolah Pelita Harapan (page does not exist)">Sekolah Pelita Harapan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[99]</a></sup>
<br style="clear:both;" />
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="International_relations">International relations</span></h2>
<p>Jakarta signed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sister_city&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sister city (page does not exist)">sister city</a> agreement with other cities, one of them is <a href="/wiki/Casablanca" title="Casablanca">Casablanca</a>, Morocco's largest city, that have signed sister city agreement on Sept. 21, 1990. To promote friendship between two cities, <i>Jalan Casablanca</i>, a main avenue famous for its shopping and business centers in <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Jakarta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Jakarta (page does not exist)">South Jakarta</a>, was named after Jakarta's Moroccan sister city. Currently there is no street in Casablanca named after Jakarta, however on the other hand in <a href="/wiki/Rabat" title="Rabat">Rabat</a>, Morocco's capital city, an avenue was named after <a href="/wiki/Sukarno" title="Sukarno">Sukarno</a>, Indonesia's first president, to commemorate his visit in 1960 also as a token of friendship.<sup id="cite_ref-JakartaPost2_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JakartaPost2-101">[100]</a></sup> Jakarta is also a member of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Asian_Network_of_Major_Cities_21&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Asian Network of Major Cities 21 (page does not exist)">Asian Network of Major Cities 21</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=C40_Cities_Climate_Leadership_Group&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="C40 Cities Climate Leadership Group (page does not exist)">C40 Cities Climate Leadership Group</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Twin_towns_.E2.80.93_Sister_cities">Twin towns – Sister cities</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<table class="wikitable">

<tr valign="top">
<td>
<dl>
<dt>Asia
</dt>
</dl>
<ol>
<li><a href="/wiki/File:Proposed_Flag_of_Islamabad_Capital_Territory.svg" title="File:Proposed Flag of Islamabad Capital Territory.svg">23px</a> <a href="/wiki/Islamabad" title="Islamabad">Islamabad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/File:Emblem_of_Tokyo.svg" title="File:Emblem of Tokyo.svg">23px</a> <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_PRC&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data PRC (page does not exist)">Template:Country data PRC</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beijing (page does not exist)">Beijing</a>, <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/File:Ph_seal_ncr_manila.svg" title="File:Ph seal ncr manila.svg">23px</a> <a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/File:Seal_of_Kuala_Lumpur.svg" title="File:Seal of Kuala Lumpur.svg">23px</a> <a href="/wiki/Kuala_Lumpur" title="Kuala Lumpur">Kuala Lumpur</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malaysia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Malaysia (page does not exist)">Malaysia</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/File:Seal_of_Seoul.svg" title="File:Seal of Seoul.svg">23px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Seoul&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Seoul (page does not exist)">Seoul</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a><sup id="cite_ref-Seoul_twinnings2_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Seoul_twinnings2-102">[101]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Seoul_twinnings_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Seoul_twinnings-103">[102]</a></sup>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Abu_Dhabi.svg" title="File:Flag of Abu Dhabi.svg">23px</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Abu_Dhabi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Abu Dhabi (page does not exist)">Abu Dhabi</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/File:Coat_of_arms_of_Saudi_Arabia.svg" title="File:Coat of arms of Saudi Arabia.svg">23px</a> <a href="/wiki/Jeddah" title="Jeddah">Jeddah</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_PRK&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data PRK (page does not exist)">Template:Country data PRK</a> <a href="/wiki/Pyongyang" title="Pyongyang">Pyongyang</a>, <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/File:Hanoi_Logo.svg" title="File:Hanoi Logo.svg">23px</a> <a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">Hanoi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/File:Seal_Bangkok.png" title="File:Seal Bangkok.png">23px</a> <a href="/wiki/Bangkok" title="Bangkok">Bangkok</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Iran&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Iran (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Iran</a> <a href="/wiki/Yazd" title="Yazd">Yazd</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>
